content: Section 233(e) of the Act is amended to allow agreements to enter into force after 60 days of transmittal to Congress, excluding certain days. Documents related to the agreement must be delivered to both Houses of Congress on the same day. The document setting forth an agreement under this section must be delivered to both Houses of Congress on the same day. It should include a determination by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration on the impact of the agreement on the social security system over a 75-year period. The agreement under this section must be delivered to Congress on the same day and include a determination by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration on its impact over a 75-year period. The actuarial balance is the difference between the adjusted summarized income rate and cost rate, while taxable payroll refers to total wages and self-employment income for a period. The adjusted summarized income rate is the ratio of the trust fund balance and total income from taxes over a period. The trust fund balance is the combined balance of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The adjusted summarized cost rate is the ratio of the cost during a period plus the targeted trust fund balance to the taxable payroll for the years in that period. The Trust Funds refer to amounts deposited based on taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term 'cost' includes disbursements for benefit payments, administrative expenses, and vocational rehabilitation services. The curr_chunk discusses the target trust fund balance needed to support an OASDI trust fund ratio of 100 percent. The Chief Actuary will use the intermediate assumptions of the Board of Trustees of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to make determinations. The Actuary will use the Board of Trustees' assumptions for the OASDI trust fund balance. Agreements must be approved within 60 days to take effect. The Chief Actuary's determination on agreements affecting the social security system's actuarial balance is crucial. The security system established by this title requires approval within 60 days to take effect. The provisions of this paragraph are enacted by Congress as part of the rules for disapproval and approval resolutions. During a 60-day period, it is a top priority in Congress to consider bills for disapproval or approval of agreements. The rules for these resolutions supersede others and can be changed by each House at any time. The amendment made by this subsection applies to totalization arrangements transmitted to Congress after the enactment date. The agreement signed by the Commissioner of Social Security in June 2004, regarding totalization arrangements between the US and another country, will not enter into force until after the enactment date, as specified in section 233(e) of the Social Security Act. The agreement on totalization arrangements between the US and another country will only come into force after the specified date in section 233(e) of the Social Security Act, subject to the President's report to Congress meeting the requirements of the amended section. Additionally, biennial reports to Congress on the ongoing operation of totalization agreements are required under the amended Section 233 of the Act. Biennial Oversight Reports are required for the ongoing operation of totalization agreements under the amended Section 233 of the Social Security Act. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit biennial reports to Congress evaluating the operation of totalization agreements, including changes in benefit costs and contributions, as well as information on fraudulent receipt of benefits. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit biennial reports to Congress evaluating totalization agreements, including information on fraudulent benefit receipt, integrity of data, and future cost trends. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit an initial report by December 31, 2008, regarding social security systems attributable to the agreement. SEC. 203. SUSPENSION OF BENEFITS FOR INDIVIDUALS REMOVED FROM THE UNITED STATES. Section 202(n)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a new provision stating that no lump sum death payment will be made to an individual after being notified of their removal from the United States by the Commissioner of Social Security. These amendments apply to individuals who have been removed from the country. Individuals notified of their removal from the United States after the twelfth month following the enactment of this Act are affected by the amendments to the Social Security Act.
